Among the eighteen elements, how many are internal and how many are external?
Verse:
The twelve internal ones are the eyes and so forth, the six forms and so forth are external.
Treatise:
The twelve, the six sense faculties and the six consciousnesses, are called internal. The external refers to the remaining six sense objects such as form.
The self is called internal, the external refers to what is other than that.
Since the self does not exist, how can there be internal and external?
It is not that there is no pure morality, there is a basis for pure morality. The master of the sÅ«tras explains it like this here:
Because it is the basis for the grasping of self, the mind is metaphorically called self.
Therefore a sÅ«tra says:
By well subduing the self, the wise one attains rebirth in the heavens.
The World-Honored One said in other places to subdue the mind, as a sÅ«tra says:
The mind should be well-tamed, for a tamed mind leads to happiness.
Therefore, the self is merely a designation for the mind.
The eyes and so on are called internal because they are the proximate supports for the mind.
Form and so on are called external because they are the objects of the mind and are more remote.
If this is so, then the six consciousnesses should not be called internal, because prior to becoming mental consciousness they are not the support for mind.

But when they become mental consciousness, they do not lose the nature of the six consciousnesses, and prior to becoming mental consciousness they do not transcend the characteristics of mental consciousness.

If this were not so, then the realm of mental consciousness would exist only in the past, and the six consciousnesses would exist only in the present and future, and this would contradict the accepted doctrine that the eighteen realms are found in all three times.

Also, if the six consciousnesses of the present and future do not have the nature of the realm of mental consciousness, then even when they reach the state of past mental consciousness they should not be established as such, because their nature does not change in the three times.
This explanation is not correct. We will now explain.
Why is it that among the mind and mental activities of one birth, one abiding, one cessation, and one fruit, etc., mind is said to be internal and mental activities are said to be external?
Are not mental activities the support of the false self and mind? They are the supported, and as such, they are extremely close to the support, and therefore they should be called internal.

Also, the eye, etc., are not always the support of visual consciousness, etc., but there is no mind that is not the support of mental activities. Therefore only mental activities should be called internal.
Or, again, what is the special reason for calling that which is the support of the false self and mind internal, and not calling that which is supported internal?
Therefore the above explanation has no profound meaning.
Also, a small part of mind is the support of self-attachment, and all minds that are supports are called internal. For this reason, you should not explain the above passage as follows:
Because it is the support of self-attachment, mind is metaphorically called self.
Also, because a small part of mind is the support of craving, etc., all minds should be defiled.
Or, if it is only a part of mind, then all would have vitarka and vicara, because they are the support of vitarka and vicara.
Since this is not so, how can that be so?
Because we cannot find a reason for the distinction.
Moreover, how can they deny that the support of self-attachment is a mental activity?
Because the view of a real self has as its object the five aggregates that are grasped.
Therefore their explanation is definitely unreasonable.
If this is so, then why is mind said to be self?
Because it is always master of itself and its objects.
Self means being always master of itself and its objects. Mind is never at any time not master of its own objects, and therefore all mind is called self.

Mental activities do not also obtain the name of self, because the thinking consciousness is the chief, because a scripture says that it travels alone, and because it can travel to its objects only by depending on mind.
Even though mental activities are also disciplined, still, because it is the most excellent, it is said that mind is disciplined.
The same is true of the term self; it refers only to mind, not to mental activities.
If a dharma is a special benefit to the mind that resembles the self, it is called internal.
Dharmas that are contrary to this are called external. Therefore there is no error in the theory that the mental activities are internal.
Also, even though the mental activities are born, endure, etc., together with the mind, the mind alone is called internal.
The reason is that the mind and its activities are of the same species, and the mind is the support of the other mental activities, which are not mutually supportive.

The mental activities are of different species from the mind, and they definitely abandon the nature of support.ğŸ”½That is, if a good mind is the support of a good, soiled, or nondefiled mind, it does not abandon them. The same is true of a soiled or nondefiled mind.
If a good mental activity is the support of a soiled or nondefiled mind, it abandons the nature of support. The same is true of a soiled or nondefiled mental activity in relation to the others.
Therefore the mind, in relation to the mind, is the support and is not distinguished as being different, and so it is called internal.
The mental activities are the supported in relation to the mind, but they are not called internal because they are distinguished by their characteristics.
Also, the mental activities are the supported in relation to the mind of the same species, but the mind is not so in relation to them.
Therefore the name internal belongs to the mind and not to the mental activities.
In that case, the great elements should be called internal.
No, because the class of mental activities is destroyed, just as the nonfallen dharmas of ordinary people.
There is another interpretation that the name internal is explained in terms of the meaning of the word, that is, because we have a dominant power over them, they are called internal.
We means self-body. We have a dominant power over the remaining dharmas.
The great virtuous KumÄralÄta says in verse:ğŸ”½If the fingernail, tip of the tongue, and so on, had no dominant power,
The functions of moving, touching, and tasting flavors would not differ.
In a collection of forms such as color, smell, taste, and touch, the body faculty alone has a dominant function, and so on up to the eye faculty.
The mind also has a dominant function with regard to the other faculties. Therefore the twelve are all called internal.
If this is so, then the distinctions in the nature of feeling, etc., are also seen to have a dominant function with regard to other faculties, and in that case all dharmas should be called internal.
Since the VaibhÄá¹£ikas of KaÅ›mÄ«r hold that all dharmas are included in the dharma realm, how do they establish the internal and external?
They say that it is like the other , i.e., the five sense bases. How is it like the other five?
That which serves as a support for the six consciousnesses is established as internal, and that which does not serve as a support for the six consciousnesses is established as external.
That which is a support is only animate, is close, and is unique, but form, etc., are not necessarily so.
They are like form, etc.
Even though they are also animate, are close, and are unique, they are not supports, and therefore they are established as external and not internal, like the eye, etc.

Although the eye, etc., are included in the sense base of dharmas, they are established as internal because they are the same as feeling, etc., and are the support, but they are not established as external. The remaining sense bases of dharmas are only called external.
Moreover, although the eye, etc., are both internal and external, the natures of internal and external are not mutually contradictory. Therefore, you should not insist on this as a difficulty.

That is to say, when they are the support for the consciousnesses of the eye, etc., they are established as internal natures. When they are the objects of consciousness as the mental faculty, they are established as external natures.
They say that just as the mental faculty is included in the internal sense bases and is the object of consciousness, it is also included in the external sense bases.
The various categories and terms that have been explained are all based on personal opinion and cannot prevent error.
There is some semblance of inference, but no true teaching or principle.
Why is this?
Because it contradicts the sutras.
As a sutra says:
Bhiká¹£us, you should know that dharmas are the external sense bases, which are dharmas not included in the eleven sense bases, which are invisible and unimpeded.
Moreover, in this scripture, not all dharmas are included in the dharma realm, because in this scripture it is said that the dharma realm is not included in the eleven sense bases.
Also, it is not only the separate dharmas conceived by them that are called the dharma realm, because in this scripture it is not said that the formless dharmas are like the sense base of mind.
That school only conceives the aggregates of feeling, perception, and impulse, which are called separate dharmas in the dharma realm, to be formless.
If in this scripture the dharma realm were explained in terms of those separate dharmas, then it should be said that they are like the formless dharmas that are invisible and unimpeded.
For this reason, in this scripture, the invisible and unimpeded dharmas that are not included in the eleven sense bases, such as the eye sense base, are extensively refuted.

If form only has visibility and resistance and there is no other form, and one wishes to directly explain the separate dharma realm, one should simply say that the dharma realm refers to the external sense bases and the sense base of mind that are not included, and are also formless.
For this reason, it is established that this separate dharma realm is not included in the eleven sense bases, is invisible, and is unimpeded.
Or else, it should be said that the formless realm is not included in the formless realm, because the term formless is not mentioned here.
Moreover, because it is denied that the formless realm is included in the sense bases, therefore the form of the dharma realm definitely exists separately.
What is this form?
It is called non-indicative form.
We will investigate this together in the Abhidharma-koÅ›a.
How does it make others know that although the sense bases such as the eye are the objects of the mind, they are only internal?
Therefore, in this sÅ«tra, the general number and specific nature are denied in order to reveal the dharma realm.

The Buddha BhagavÄn, observing the future world, saw that in the place where he was born, there would be those who claimed to be ÅšÄkyamuni's disciples, who would hold that all dharmas are the dharma realm.
In order to refute them, he clearly said, The dharma realm is only this, not all dharmas.

Therefore, only in the explanation of the characteristics of the dharma realm, the term not included in the eleven sense bases is used, because the eye, etc. do not have the meaning of mutual inclusion. In the sense bases such as the eye, there is no such statement;
Because mental consciousness can take all dharmas as objects, it should not be the case that all dharmas are included in the dharma realm.
Therefore, here it is refuted in this way.

Moreover, the Sthavira's further establishment of the eyes, etc., as having both internal and external natures, definitely should not be established, because there has never been a place where it is said that when those eyes, etc., serve as the support for eye consciousness, etc., they are established as having an internal nature, and when they serve as the objects of mental consciousness, they are established as having an external nature.
By this, the mental faculty cited by him is refuted, because it is like the eyes, etc., which have never been spoken of.
How is it that the teacher who claims to be good at resolving difficulties himself establishes a similar example without being known?

Since he is able to do this, why does he bring up the mind from afar?ğŸ”½In order to establish that the eye faculty has both internal and external natures, he should only bring up the ear as a similar dharma;
in order to establish that the ear faculty has both internal and external natures, he should also bring up the eye as a similar dharma.
The Sthavira's statement that the established eyes, etc., have both internal and external natures, definitely should be established, just as the World-Honored One said:
Bhiká¹£us should know that all eyes, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, and so on, are explained in detail in the same way for the mind.
If that is so, then there is the fault of excess, as a sÅ«tra says:
Dwelling in the body, one observes the body. And so on, it is explained in detail.
Also, as a sÅ«tra says:
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, and so on, are explained in detail.
Since there is no internal nature in forms and so on, the sÅ«tra should not say the words all that is. How can there be internal in feelings, perceptions, and volitional formations?
Also, it was said earlier that if it serves as the basis for the six consciousnesses, it is established as internal.
Since this is accepted, forms and so on, feelings and so on, which are not the basis of consciousness, should be called only external. Why does the sÅ«tra say internal?
Just as forms, feelings, and so on are said to be internal, but are not internal sense bases, they are only included in the external sense bases.
Although it is said that the eye, etc., are external, they are not included in the sense base of dharmas, but are only internal sense bases.
If this is so, what is the meaning of the scripture?
We should seek the meaning of this scripture together.
What you said above is not reasonable. I will now explain the meaning of this scripture.
The eye, etc., are called internal because they are the support for consciousness, and form, etc., are called external because they are the objects of consciousness.
There is no dispute about this.

Moreover, the eye faculty, which is the support for consciousness, is called internal when it has already, is now, or will be born, and is called external when it is contrary to this. The same is so for the internal and external of the mind faculty. Form, etc., which are objects, are called internal when they occur in the same body as the consciousness that supports them, and are called external when they are contrary to this.
In this way, internal and external are established according to location and the body that supports them. This does not contradict the holy teachings and accords with the characteristics of dharmas.

Therefore the position of the elder that the eye, etc., are definitely internal or external is not established. Not only is it not established, but the characteristics are also confused, because it is held that the eye, etc., are the basis and objects of consciousness and are considered to be internal or external, and the characteristics are confused.
That is to say, when the mental consciousness arises taking as its object the basis of support, the mind, to which category should this mind be assigned?
It should not be internal, because it is the object of the mental consciousness;
it should not be external, because it is the basis of support of the mental consciousness;

it should not be internal and external, because it is not mentioned in the scriptures, because there is no scripture that says that the mind faculty is either internal, or external, or both internal and external.
Isn't it said that there is an internal and external mind?
This is said in terms of the basis of support of the mind.
If this interpretation is not accepted, then the internal nature of feeling, etc., would not be established.
Also, one would not be endowed with the three contemplations with regard to mind, because there would be no contemplation of mind in the case of the mind that is only external.
They maintain that when the mind is the object of manas, it is called external,
but it is also called internal, because the mind is always the support of consciousness.
If you admit that when manas is the object of manas, it is also called internal, what is wrong with that?
It is not the case that sometimes the eye, etc., are not the support for the consciousness that they generate.
Thus the position of the Sthavira that the internal and external sense bases violate the scriptures and are not well established is confused.
Only the position of the great Ä€bhidharmikas is in accord with the scriptures, is well established, and is not confused.

Among the eighteen sense bases, how many are similar and how many are dissimilar?
The verse states:
The dharma sense base is similar; the other two are both similar and dissimilar, in performing or not performing their own function.
The treatise states:
The dharma sense base refers to the dharma sense base alone, which is only similar.
We should first explain the characteristics of the similar objects.
If an object is definitely the object-support of a consciousness, then the dharma realm is definitely the object-support of mental consciousness, because it is not shared.
The object-support that has already arisen or is arising in that consciousness is called the similar class, because mental consciousness can universally take all objects as its object.

Among the objects of the three times and the unconditioned, there is not a single dharma realm that has not already, is not now, or will not arise as mental consciousness, because the mental consciousness of two moments is able to universally take all dharmas as its object. Therefore, the dharma realm is always called the similar class.
The other two means the remaining seventeen sense bases have both the similar class and the dissimilar class.
What are called the similar class and the dissimilar class?
It means performing one's own function and not performing one's own function.
If one performs one's own function, it is called the similar class; if one does not perform one's own function, it is called the dissimilar class.
How are the eye, etc. called the similar class and the dissimilar class?
First, the similar class eye is said to be of three kinds: that which has already seen, is now seeing, or will see forms in the form realm.
The homogeneous eye is said to be of four kinds: that which is opposed to the above, and that which is not yet arisen.

Western masters say that the homogeneous eye is of five kinds, because that which is not yet arisen is divided into two, due to the difference in characteristics of having consciousness and not having consciousness.
As with the eye, so it is with the ear, nose, tongue, and body, each of which should be said to have its own function with regard to its own object.
The homogeneous mental faculty is said to be of three kinds: that which has already, is now, or will in the future cognize its object.
The non-homogeneous mental faculty is of only one kind, namely that which is not yet arisen.
The homogeneous form is said to be of three kinds: that which is seen by the eye and has already, is now, or will in the future cease.
The non-homogeneous form is said to be of four kinds: that which is opposed to the above, and that which is not yet arisen.
This is extensively applied up to the tactile object, each of which should be said to have its own function with regard to its own faculty.
The six consciousnesses of the eye, etc., are established as two kinds based on whether they are arisen or not arisen, just like the mental faculty.
If the eye is homogeneous with one, it is also homogeneous with all the others;
If it is a similar class for one, it is also a similar class for all others.
... up to... the same is true for the mind faculty.
This is not so for form. For one who sees it, it is a similar class; for one who does not see it, it is a dissimilar class.
Or there are forms that exist on the lofty mountains such as Sumeru, which for all sentient beings are a dissimilar class.
Because they are useless, even those with the divine eye do not observe them.
Or there are forms that are a similar class for only one sentient being, like those that one privately observes oneself.
Or there are forms that are a similar class for hundreds of thousands of sentient beings, like those that many people observe together, such as the moon, dancing, wrestling, and so on.
What is the reason for saying that the similar class and dissimilar class of the eye are different from form?
It is possible for many sentient beings to see the same form, but one eye is useless for two sentient beings to observe with.
Sound is explained like form, because it is a shared object.
The three of smell, taste, and touch are as explained in the internal realms, because they are not shared objects.

However, in the world based on provisional names and concepts, there are those who say, We all smell this fragrance together, we all taste this flavor together, we all feel this touch together. What is meant by similar?
The meaning of similar is that they have this part in common.
How do they have this in common?
It means that the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses interact with each other. This is the meaning of mutually following each other.
Or, part refers to the already functioning that interacts with each other.
Therefore, it was said earlier that if it performs its own function, it is called similar.

Or, part refers to the contact that arises based on the interaction of the faculties, objects, and consciousnesses. Because they have this part in common, it is called similar, which means having the same function and the same contact.
The opposite of this is called dissimilar. Because the dissimilar is of the same kind as the similar, it is called dissimilar.
How is it of the same kind as that?

That is to say, they are the same in terms of the characteristics of seeing, etc., the same in terms of place, and the same in terms of realm, because they are mutually causal, because they are mutually dependent, and because they mutually attract. The division of their kinds is the same.
The homogeneous and the heterogeneous have already been explained.

Non-defiled ones not born of the six are not eliminated by seeing.

Only eliminated by cultivation means that these fifteen elements are only eliminated by cultivation.
The last three elements are the mental element, the element of factors, and the element of mental consciousness, because they are said to be the last of the six triads.
Of three kinds means that these last three elements are each of three kinds.
The eighty-eight proclivities, the mind and mental activities associated with them, the possession of these, and the dharmas that are born with them, etc., are all eliminated by the path of insight.
The rest of the impure dharmas are eliminated by the path of cultivation.
All pure dharmas are not eliminated.

Therefore the defiled actions of body and speech that provoke the evil destinies are also eliminated by the path of insight, because they all oppose the path of insight.
In order to refute this, it is said that the uncontaminated and the form not born of the six sense bases are definitely not eliminated by insight.

If it were contaminated, then ordinary beings in the desire realm who have already separated from desire for the desire realm would not be ordinary beings.

If it were good, then those who have cut off the good roots would not be ordinary beings.
Therefore it is categorized as uncontaminated and indeterminate.
Since it is not contaminated, it is not eliminated by insight. If it were eliminated by insight, it would be eliminated by the patience stage.
If it were eliminated by the patience stage, then one would still possess it when patience is present, and therefore the noble one would also be an ordinary being.
Also, uncontaminated dharmas are definitely not eliminated by insight, because they are said to be eliminated when the passions that take them as objects are ultimately eliminated.
Also, they are not born of the six sense bases, and they are also not eliminated by insight.

If a dharma is a fetter and has one fruit, etc., when the antidote arises, one obtains the severing of that dharma, called â€œsevering by intrinsic nature.â€ Because of the severing of that dharma, one obtains disjunction from the objective realm.
It is not necessary to obtain non-possession in that dharma, which is called â€œsevering by objective realm.â€

Here, all contaminated form, and defiled and undefiled contaminated formlessness, and the dharmas such as birth that arise on the basis of those dharmas, are bound by the fetters that are severed by seeing and by cultivation.

When these fetters are gradually severed, the attainment of disjunction arises on the basis of each individual category. At that time, those fetters and their one fruit, etc., are all called â€œalready severed.â€

The contaminated form, and defiled and undefiled contaminated formlessness, and the attainments of disjunction from those dharmas such as birth, do not yet arise at that time, and are not yet called â€œsevered,â€ because those dharmas are only severed by the final uninterrupted path of that stage.
The path of insight cannot sever attachment to realms and stages in order, so how can it sever form, etc.?

When one sees the noble truths, dharmas of evil destinies are not born again because of the support of various conditions. However, they are not yet said to be severed because their associated passions have not yet been completely severed.
If a dharma is not yet severed and is not born or not accomplished, what is the difference between this and that which has been severed?
Severance is said to be the path of countering that causes one to be free from bonds, not that it is not born or not accomplished.
First, it is not called severance because it is not born, because this is indefinite.
Why is this?
There are dharmas that are already severed but that are still born, such as the results of retribution in the body, etc., according to circumstances.
There are dharmas that are already severed and also not born, such as the view of a person, etc.

There are dharmas that are not yet severed and that are not born, such as all dharmas that are not born in the past and future of an Ärya whose passions have not yet been exhausted, such as love, etc., in the body.
If one has already attained the forbearance of the unconditioned, then wrong views and so forth are all like this, and one may be born without having yet eliminated them.
Like the remaining dharmas, according to their application, they are also not incomplete, and therefore they are called eliminated.
They are also not definite.
Why is this?

There may be some that are already eliminated but still accomplished, like the undefiled dharmas in that body. According to their application, the defiled dharmas, if they are already eliminated, are definitely not accomplished.

Or defiled dharmas, although they have not yet been eliminated, are not accomplished, like one who has not yet abandoned desire who attains the turning of the precepts that follow. The evil of violating the precepts is abandoned but not eliminated, because it is eliminated by the final uninterrupted path.
Bodily and verbal actions are not gradually eliminated in nine grades. The faults of defiled ones are also few.
In this way, there may be some that are not yet eliminated but still accomplished, like the remaining dharmas according to their application.
Other masters say:
The two kinds of actions, bodily and vocal, that attract evil destinies are not eliminated by the path of insight, because they are born of close attachment.
They are not eliminated by the path of insight. Others have raised objections to this, saying,
We see that actions born of close attachment in other classes are able to be eternally eliminated only by the path of insight of other classes.
Therefore the above explanation is definitely not reasonable.
This objection is not reasonable, because it must be carefully considered.
We also see that actions born of close attachment in a class are able to be eternally eliminated by the path of insight of that class.
Why not use this to prove the above?
If actions are eliminated by insight, they must be born of close attachment, but we cannot take them as a fixed class.
The fixed classes are separated by the power of nonpervasive passions. Therefore, although there are thirteen classes, five classes are said to constitute fixed classes.
Consequently, we know that the two kinds of actions, bodily and vocal, if born of close attachment in a class, are eliminated by the path of insight of that class.
Since these actions are not born of close attachment to the passions that are eliminated by insight, they are not eliminated by the path of insight.
Therefore, their explanation is not unreasonable.
However, a sutra says:
The bodily, verbal, and mental actions produced by those with wrong views are all wrong.
This is not contradictory. The sutra only says that the three actions produced by those with wrong views are not said to be the three actions produced by wrong views.
Or, it is said that this action is produced by the greed, etc., that are eliminated by cultivation, which are caused by wrong views, and which are the direct cause of its arising.

However, the greed, etc., that are eliminated by cultivation, can be the proximate cause and direct cause of the arising of this action. Therefore, it is said that the two karmas of body and speech that are impure are only eliminated by cultivation.
Also, a sutra says that a stream-enterer says:
I have already exhausted the hells, etc.
This means that he obtains non-analytical cessation with regard to them, and they are never born again, so it is called exhausted.
Here there is a question:
If future dharmas are never born again and are called exhausted, what is the characteristic of these unborn dharmas?
It should be called a non-perishing dharma like the past.
But at that time it has no substance at all, so how can it be said to be a dharma that arises or does not arise?
